item.title: About me
item.description: I am a climate scientist. I try to understand what Earth’s climate would look like now, if not for human activities like greenhouse gas and aerosol emissions. Part of that involves understanding modern climate dynamics. Another part involves studying climate variability in the time before the Industrial Revolution. Figuring out the difference between those two things helps us to understand how and why Earth’s climate is changing today, and hence how it might change in the future.

item.title: News
item.description: 29 OCTOBER 2024 Just out in Weather and Climate Extremes: we show that the severity of Australia’s 2017-2019 ‘Tinderbox’ drought (the one that preceded the 2019/20 bushfires) was likely made worse by climate change. We use Linear Inverse Models to produce 10,000 years of ‘pseudo-observations’ of Australian rainfall and global SST anomalies, and use these to quantify the full natural range of natural variability in Australian rainfall. Turns out, rainfall deficits over the Murray-Darling Basin during the Tinderbox Drought fall outside that range.
